Award.AwardTitle: The Systems Biology of Mammalian Puberty
Award.AbstractNarration: During the last several years, investigators have observed an earlier initiation of human female puberty, a worrisome trend because early puberty is associated with increased risk for cancer, obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease. It has also become clear that the timing of puberty is under genetic control, and likely determined by a host of regulatory genes. Yet, few attempts have been made to identify the genetic networks controlling this critical milestone in mammalian development. Drs. Sergio Ojeda (a neuroscientist) and Kemal Sönmez (a computer/electrical engineer) have combined expertise and developed a partnership between biology and engineering to test the hypothesis that a repressive gene network operating within the brain controls the initiation of female puberty. Using a combination of computational methods, systems biology approaches and molecular strategies, they performed preliminary studies revealing the existence of such a network and showing that it represses subordinate genes, which if left unchecked, would unleash the pubertal process prematurely. To disseminate their findings, Ojeda and Sönmez will partner with the Institute for Systems Biology in Seattle to generate a database resource of Web-based tools, links and protocols for analyses accessible via Internet. They will also make their raw data, results, and codes available on their website (www.sonmezsysbio.org), and deposit their data and results in public databases. Because the research plan includes the participation of undergraduate students and high-school students, The project will encourage young investigators to use similar integrative approaches for the study of many other complex physiological processes in mammalian systems. Theses studies will significantly enhance the understanding of basic systems-wide mechanisms underlying the neuroendocrine control of mammalian puberty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A critical milestone in human life is the attainment of sexual maturity, which allows the perpetuation of our species. This transcendental event occurs at the time of puberty, and is accompanied by profound physical and behavioral changes.  In recent years there has been a renewed tendency for puberty to occur earlier in girls, but the causes for this propensity remain unknown.  Although there is little doubt that our genetic make-up plays an important role in determining the timing and progression of puberty, changes in DNA sequence explain less than 5% of cases of either delayed or premature activation of the pubertal process, and even less of the normal variation of pubertal timing. Our studies have provided for the first time an inkling of how the environment can affect the timing of puberty. We have identified epigenetic mechanisms (i.e. dynamic changes in gene expression without changing the primary nucleotide sequence of a gene) that affect reproductive maturation by modifying the activity of genes involved in setting puberty in motion. Our results demonstrated the existence of a balance between inhibitory and stimulatory epigenetic factors operating in a region of the brain known as the hypothalamus, whose major function is to connect the nervous system to the endocrine system. Before puberty, a repressive epigenetic force provided by a gene silencing complex predominates. As puberty approaches, the balance switches to stimulation, and this driving force is provided by a regulatory gene complex that promotes gene activity.  Our results suggest that environmental factors, such as nutritional status, pollutants/toxins, and alterations in day-night dependent biological rhythms may affect the timing of puberty by differentially tilting the balance between these two fundamental inhibitory and stimulatory forces of epigenetic regulation.  We anticipate that our studies will help researchers and clinicians to identify epigenetic pathways linking environmental cues to changes in the activity of genes involved in controlling the initiation of puberty.
